chapters.detailed_explanation: The First Estate consisted of clergy, the Second Estate of nobility, and the Third Estate of common people who paid most taxes but had no political power. The French Revolution was caused by social inequality, economic crisis, and political mismanagement. The middle class led the revolution by spreading ideas of liberty and equality. The storming of the Bastille on 14 July 1789 marked the beginning of the French Revolution. A charter of fundamental rights adopted by the French National Assembly in 1789. Symbols used by revolutionaries to communicate revolutionary ideas. A radical political group led by Robespierre. A period of extreme violence from 1793–1794. Women participated actively but were denied political rights. Slavery was abolished in 1794 but later reintroduced. Napoleon rose to power and ended revolutionary democracy.

concepts.name: French Society in the Late Eighteenth Century
concepts.definition: French society before the revolution was divided into three estates based on social and economic status.
concepts.intuition: Society was unequal by birth, not by effort.
concepts.explanation: The First Estate consisted of clergy, the Second Estate of nobility, and the Third Estate of common people who paid most taxes but had no political power.
concepts.why_it_matters: This inequality was the root cause of the French Revolution.

concepts.name: Causes of the French Revolution
concepts.definition: The French Revolution was caused by social inequality, economic crisis, and political mismanagement.

concepts.name: Role of the Middle Class
concepts.definition: The middle class led the revolution by spreading ideas of liberty and equality.

concepts.name: Storming of the Bastille
concepts.definition: The storming of the Bastille on 14 July 1789 marked the beginning of the French Revolution.

concepts.name: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen
concepts.definition: A charter of fundamental rights adopted by the French National Assembly in 1789.

concepts.name: Political Symbols
concepts.definition: Symbols used by revolutionaries to communicate revolutionary ideas.

concepts.name: The Jacobins
concepts.definition: A radical political group led by Robespierre.

concepts.name: The Reign of Terror
concepts.definition: A period of extreme violence from 1793–1794.

concepts.name: Role of Women
concepts.definition: Women participated actively but were denied political rights.

concepts.name: Abolition of Slavery
concepts.definition: Slavery was abolished in 1794 but later reintroduced.

concepts.name: Rise of Napoleon Bonaparte
concepts.definition: Napoleon rose to power and ended revolutionary democracy.

concepts.name: Socialism
concepts.definition: An ideology advocating collective ownership of resources.

concepts.name: The Russian Revolution
concepts.definition: A 1917 revolution that overthrew the Tsarist regime.

concepts.name: Role of the Bolsheviks
concepts.definition: A socialist group led by Lenin.

concepts.name: Impact of the Russian Revolution
concepts.definition: It reshaped global politics and inspired socialism worldwide.

chapters.chapter_name: Socialism in Europe and the Russian Revolution
chapters.detailed_explanation: Socialists believed capitalism caused inequality and exploitation of workers. Economic hardship, autocracy, and World War I led to mass unrest. Strikes and protests forced the Tsar to abdicate. Led by Lenin, the Bolsheviks took control of the government. It inspired socialist movements across the world.

concepts.name: Socialism
concepts.definition: Socialism is a political and economic system that advocates collective ownership of resources.
concepts.intuition: Resources should be shared, not controlled by a few.
concepts.explanation: Socialists believed capitalism caused inequality and exploitation of workers.
concepts.why_it_matters: It introduced ideas that reshaped modern politics.

concepts.name: The Russian Revolution
concepts.definition: The Russian Revolution was a series of events in 1917 that ended Tsarist rule.
concepts.intuition: Oppression and war pushed people to revolt.
concepts.explanation: Economic hardship, autocracy, and World War I led to mass unrest.
concepts.why_it_matters: It led to the formation of the Soviet Union.

concepts.name: February Revolution
concepts.definition: A revolution that overthrew the Tsar in February 1917.
concepts.explanation: Strikes and protests forced the Tsar to abdicate.
concepts.why_it_matters: It ended centuries of monarchy in Russia.

concepts.name: October Revolution
concepts.definition: A revolution led by the Bolsheviks in October 1917.
concepts.explanation: Led by Lenin, the Bolsheviks took control of the government.
concepts.why_it_matters: It established a socialist state.

concepts.name: Impact of the Russian Revolution
concepts.definition: The revolution influenced politics worldwide.
concepts.explanation: It inspired socialist movements across the world.
concepts.why_it_matters: It reshaped global politics in the 20th century.

chapters.chapter_name: Nazism and the Rise of Hitler
chapters.detailed_explanation: Economic crisis and political instability weakened it. Germany lost territory and had to pay heavy reparations. Industries shut down and unemployment increased. He promised jobs, national pride, and strong leadership. They believed in Aryan supremacy and hated Jews.

concepts.name: Weimar Republic
concepts.definition: A democratic government established in Germany after World War I.
concepts.explanation: Economic crisis and political instability weakened it.
concepts.why_it_matters: Its failure led to dictatorship.

concepts.name: Treaty of Versailles
concepts.definition: A treaty that punished Germany after World War I.
concepts.explanation: Germany lost territory and had to pay heavy reparations.
concepts.why_it_matters: It created anger and resentment.

concepts.name: Economic Crisis of 1929
concepts.definition: A global depression that severely affected Germany.
concepts.explanation: Industries shut down and unemployment increased.
concepts.why_it_matters: People lost faith in democracy.

concepts.name: Rise of Hitler
concepts.definition: Adolf Hitler rose to power by exploiting public fear.
concepts.intuition: People trusted strong promises in weak times.
concepts.explanation: He promised jobs, national pride, and strong leadership.
concepts.why_it_matters: It led to dictatorship and World War II.

concepts.name: Nazi Ideology
concepts.definition: An ideology based on extreme nationalism and racism.
concepts.intuition: Nazis believed some races were superior.
concepts.explanation: They believed in Aryan supremacy and hated Jews.
concepts.why_it_matters: It caused genocide and mass violence.

chapters.detailed_explanation: The British restricted access to forests to extract timber for railways and ships. Forests were classified into reserved, protected, and village forests. People were banned from grazing, collecting wood, and shifting cultivation. The Bastar Rebellion was a major uprising against forest laws. Natural forests were replaced with single-species plantations.

concepts.name: Colonial Control over Forests
concepts.definition: Colonial governments took control of forests to exploit them for commercial purposes.
concepts.intuition: Forests became sources of profit, not livelihood.
concepts.explanation: The British restricted access to forests to extract timber for railways and ships.
concepts.why_it_matters: It changed forest use and harmed local communities.

concepts.name: Forest Laws
concepts.definition: Laws were made to regulate and restrict forest use.
concepts.intuition: Law favored the rulers, not the people.
concepts.explanation: Forests were classified into reserved, protected, and village forests.
concepts.why_it_matters: Traditional rights of forest dwellers were taken away.

concepts.name: Impact on Forest Communities
concepts.definition: Forest communities lost access to land and resources.
concepts.explanation: People were banned from grazing, collecting wood, and shifting cultivation.
concepts.why_it_matters: Led to poverty, hunger, and resistance.

concepts.name: Forest Revolts
concepts.definition: Forest communities resisted colonial forest policies.
concepts.intuition: People fight back when survival is threatened.
concepts.explanation: The Bastar Rebellion was a major uprising against forest laws.
concepts.why_it_matters: Shows grassroots resistance to colonialism.

concepts.name: Scientific Forestry
concepts.definition: A system to manage forests for timber production.
concepts.explanation: Natural forests were replaced with single-species plantations.
concepts.why_it_matters: It damaged biodiversity and ecosystems.

chapters.detailed_explanation: Pastoralists moved with their animals in search of pasture and water. Grazing lands were taken over for farming, railways, and forests. Pastoralists were monitored and restricted. Some reduced herd sizes, others took up farming. Climate change and land loss continue to affect pastoralists.

concepts.name: Pastoral Nomadism
concepts.definition: A lifestyle based on herding animals and seasonal movement.
concepts.explanation: Pastoralists moved with their animals in search of pasture and water.
concepts.why_it_matters: Explains sustainable use of dry lands.

concepts.name: Impact of Colonial Rule
concepts.definition: Colonial policies restricted movement of pastoralists.
concepts.explanation: Grazing lands were taken over for farming, railways, and forests.
concepts.why_it_matters: Pastoral livelihoods were severely affected.

concepts.name: Criminal Tribes Act
concepts.definition: A law that labeled many pastoral communities as criminal by birth.
concepts.explanation: Pastoralists were monitored and restricted.
concepts.why_it_matters: It stigmatized entire communities.

concepts.name: Changes in Grazing Patterns
concepts.definition: Pastoralists adapted to restrictions by changing routes and practices.
concepts.explanation: Some reduced herd sizes, others took up farming.
concepts.why_it_matters: Shows human adaptability.

concepts.name: Pastoralism Today
concepts.definition: Pastoralism still exists but faces modern challenges.
concepts.explanation: Climate change and land loss continue to affect pastoralists.
concepts.why_it_matters: Important for understanding sustainable livelihoods.

chapters.detailed_explanation: Drainage patterns depend on slope, rock structure, and climate. Common patterns include dendritic, trellis, radial, and rectangular. Includes Indus, Ganga, and Brahmaputra systems. Includes Godavari, Krishna, Kaveri, and Narmada. Lakes regulate river flow and support biodiversity.

concepts.name: Drainage System
concepts.definition: A drainage system refers to the network of rivers and streams in an area.
concepts.intuition: Rivers act like veins of the land.
concepts.explanation: Drainage patterns depend on slope, rock structure, and climate.
concepts.why_it_matters: Drainage affects agriculture, settlement, and ecosystems.

concepts.name: Major Drainage Patterns
concepts.definition: Drainage patterns describe the arrangement of rivers.
concepts.explanation: Common patterns include dendritic, trellis, radial, and rectangular.
concepts.why_it_matters: Helps understand landforms and geology.

concepts.name: The Himalayan Rivers
concepts.definition: Rivers that originate from the Himalayas and are perennial.
concepts.explanation: Includes Indus, Ganga, and Brahmaputra systems.
concepts.why_it_matters: They support dense population and agriculture.

concepts.name: The Peninsular Rivers
concepts.definition: Rivers originating in the Peninsular Plateau.
concepts.explanation: Includes Godavari, Krishna, Kaveri, and Narmada.
concepts.why_it_matters: Important for irrigation and power generation.

concepts.name: Lakes
concepts.definition: Lakes are standing bodies of water on land.
concepts.explanation: Lakes regulate river flow and support biodiversity.
concepts.why_it_matters: They help in flood control and tourism.

chapters.detailed_explanation: Climate includes temperature, rainfall, wind, and humidity. Latitude, altitude, distance from sea, winds, and relief affect climate. Southwest monsoon brings most of India’s rainfall. Cold weather, hot weather, southwest monsoon, and retreating monsoon. Human activities increase greenhouse gases.

concepts.name: Climate
concepts.definition: Climate refers to the average weather conditions over a long period.
concepts.explanation: Climate includes temperature, rainfall, wind, and humidity.
concepts.why_it_matters: Climate affects crops, lifestyle, and economy.

concepts.name: Factors Affecting Climate
concepts.definition: Several factors influence the climate of a place.
concepts.explanation: Latitude, altitude, distance from sea, winds, and relief affect climate.
concepts.why_it_matters: Explains regional climate differences.

concepts.name: Indian Monsoon
concepts.definition: A seasonal wind system that brings rainfall to India.
concepts.explanation: Southwest monsoon brings most of India’s rainfall.
concepts.why_it_matters: Indian agriculture depends on monsoon.

concepts.name: Seasons of India
concepts.definition: India has four main climatic seasons.
concepts.explanation: Cold weather, hot weather, southwest monsoon, and retreating monsoon.
concepts.why_it_matters: Helps understand rainfall and temperature patterns.

concepts.name: Climate Change
concepts.definition: Long-term changes in temperature and weather patterns.
concepts.explanation: Human activities increase greenhouse gases.
concepts.why_it_matters: Impacts environment, health, and economy.
